Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another The use of antibiotics as a diagnostic tool is bad medicine. If in the states, I'd recommend a second opinion on reading the biopsy samples. His Gleason score may be higher. They can be misread. Cancer with low PSA can be higher risk. Even if the biopsy is being read correctly treatment is recommended because of the volume. There may be higher Gleason that is undetected. With this disease success is achieved with early detection and early treatment. What treatment options are available to you? Thank you for your response! Yes I know that is Not a good idea to have antibiotice that is Why I immediatly went on doing MRI. I will request a second opinion regarding pathological report. there is clearly a discontinuity between existing data. I was planned to go for Da Vinci surgery in Germany. In our country have Da Vinci surgery available but with no much experience. But right now I dont know is the right way to action. Thank you again.

Posts.Title: PCa with normal PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic There is no reason to have robotic surgery if you can't find a good, experienced surgeon. The advantages are not worth it. Much better to have an open RP with a veteran surgeon with much experience and excellent outcomes. That is why we chose to go to another country. the center we go in has an experience of over 10,000 interventions since 2006 and our doctor about 4000 robotic surgeries. But is the surgery appropriate for my father?
Posts.Title: PCa with normal PSA

Posts.Content: my concern is whether it is early enough detected to have a good outcome. based on the data we have seems quite advanced. what do you think?
Posts.Title: PCa with normal PSA

Posts.Content: Hello everybody! I am new here and I am writing in behalf of my father recently diagnosed with PCa. He is 64 yo. I will give the case below. 10.2015 PSA 3,310 12.2017 PSA 4.480 with Free PSA 0.684 and free PSA/ total PSA 15% DRE : no lumb Ultrasound exam: no abnormalities. The urologist gave him one month antibiotics cure and repeat PSA after. I choose to make an MRI 01.2018 multiparametric MRI 3T: prostate volume 27 cc Moderate hipertrophyc transitional area multicystic/ mutinodular Periferic area- in the middle 1/3 of left lobe oval , meniscoidale area of maximum 10 mm- PIRAD 4 whitout contact with prostatic capsula. No lymph node increased in dimension Seminal vesicles with simetric reduces distension with moderate T2 hipointense content. 02.2018 fusion biopsy 12 cores + 3 target from suspected area. 6/15 positive cores Target 1: 5 mm Gleason 3 pattern from 12 mm Target 2: 6 mm gleason 3 pattern from 9 mm Target 3: 13 mm gleason 3 pattern from 13 mm Left lobe : appex 10 mm gleason 3 from 10 mm Middle 7 mm gleason 3 pattern from 14 mm Lateral appex 3 gleason 3 pattern from 14 mm. No extraprostatic extension, no perineural invasion, no angiolymphatic invasion, no necrosis. 29.02.2018 PSA after antibiotic 3,760 The URO said that is 50% probability the cancer to be exceed capsula to the appex because of the less tissue in that rea. Is possible to be such an advanced cancer with Gleason 6 and normal PSa? Does that MRI description of seminal vesicles corresponds to an invasion at that level? Which should be the therapeutic approach in your opinion? Is there a chance of curative treatment or at least 15 years survival? Thank you all for existing. Sorry about my english is not my native language we are located in Eastern Europe. Sincerely yours , a very worried daughter.
Posts.Title: PCa with normal PSA
